As a Vaishnava and a Sri Krishna devotee, I subscribe to the Vedic Indic and Upanishadic view of death. The Bhagavad Gita, in chapter two, gives a well known Vedic Indic description of the soul, or atman, and its transmigration from one body to another one. In Hinduism one finds a three world, three body cosmogony which is very interesting, indeed. The ultimate goal in Hinduism is to achieve moksha, which is liberation from the three worlds and three bodies of transmigration. The soul then is reunited with the ParaBrahman. The soul, or atman, is then fully reintegrated with Nirguna Brahman. NB is conceived of as pure, Unchanging, Undifferentiated Consciousness. He is the sole constitutive reality, and the substratum upon which everything rests. He is eternal and never dies. He is transcendant and immanent. The Hindu saying is: Satyam Jnanam Anantam Brahman. Jai Shree Krishna forever and ever adorable ones!
